item.title: ECB Likely to Stay Cautious With Rate Rises Despite Inflation Fight
item.description: The ECB’s fight against inflation remains relentless but its wariness over the economic impact of the tightening cycle is likely to make it slow the pace of its interest-rate rise next week, according to asset manager Amundi.

item.title: Exxon, Chevron Profits Are Resilient Even as Oil Prices Drop
item.description: Exxon Mobil and Chevron collectively posted $18 billion in first-quarter profits, showing resilient performance even as oil and natural-gas prices declined.

item.title: Beijing's Bain Raid, Espionage Law are Self-Sabotage
item.description: China’s economy is bouncing back. Recent moves show that the potential for state overreach is, too.

item.title: Russian Missile Barrage Kills 13 in Ukraine
item.description: Russia targeted cities across Ukraine in the most severe missile barrage in more than a month, killing at least 13 people, as the Kremlin called for expanding the development and use of drones.

item.title: ICBC Reported Flat Net-Profit Growth in First Quarter
item.description: Industrial & Commercial Bank of China reported flat growth in first-quarter net profit and a 4.8% drop in net interest income.

item.title: I Cloned Myself With AI. She Fooled My Bank and My Family.
item.description: Our columnist replaced herself with AI voice and video to see how humanlike the tech can be. The results were eerie.

item.title: Regulators to Publish Postmortems on SVB, Signature Failures
item.description: The reports are expected to include recommendations for stricter regulation of regional banks.

item.title: 'That's Just Crazy': The Metropolis Where Rents Rise 60%, 75%, Even 100%
item.description: It’s a tough time to be a tenant in Singapore, with rent increases outpacing those in London and New York.

item.title: Wage Growth, Inflation Data to Inform Fed Before Rate Decision
item.description: The government will release the employment-cost index and the price gauge watched by the central bank.

item.title: Europe's Green-Energy Push Struggles to Match U.S. Momentum
item.description: Solar and other clean-energy initiatives in Europe are being overshadowed as U.S. tax credits draw the focus of investors.

item.title: The Most Annoying Hotel Guest Is the EV Charger Hog
item.description: More electric vehicles mean more competition for chargers during overnight stays.

item.title: 'Too Many Seats, Too Few Butts' Mean Changes at Your Favorite Restaurant
item.description: As eating out is replaced by ordering out, restaurant real estate gets a radical makeover

item.title: Polls' Representative Samples Often Merit Skepticism
item.description: Polling has departed from random sampling, leading to potential source errors and a lack of transparency.

item.title: Three Soldiers Killed After U.S. Army Helicopters Collide in Alaska
item.description: Two U.S. Army helicopters collided after a training mission, marking the latest tragedy involving military aircraft in the U.S. in recent months.

item.title: Chinese Warships and Planes Test Taiwan Defenses
item.description: The 38 warplanes and six ships detected around the island represented the biggest deployment since earlier this month, when China sent aircraft and vessels to the area after Taiwan’s president returned from a visit to the U.S.

item.title: PetroChina's First-Quarter Net Profit Rose on Higher Sales Volume
item.description: PetroChina’s net profit rose in the first quarter, primarily due to a rise in domestic sales volume for major oil and gas products.

item.title: Europe's Economy Avoids Recession---Just About
item.description: A rebound in factory output and falling energy costs helped drive a modest rebound, but further interest-rate rises will test the region’s resilience.

item.title: Eurozone Bond Yields Fall on German 1Q GDP Miss
item.description: Ten-year eurozone government bond yields fell by 8 to 9 points across the board as investors digest weaker-than-expected GDP data in Germany in the first quarter.

item.title: China Politburo Says Expanding Demand Is Crucial to Continuing Current Recovery
item.description: Ensuring that China’s domestic demand continues to expand remains a critical question for the current economic recovery, the Communist Party’s top policy-making body said.

item.title: Bank of Japan's Dovish Line Pushes Yen Down, Stocks Up
item.description: The market thinks the Bank of Japan’s new governor is negative for the yen and a plus for stocks, at least based on his first policy board meeting.
